ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about different techniques to test and analyze various materials in a way that can't be learned form a textbook.
Techniques for metal processing and characterization, as well as lab reports and presentations
In this class, we had hands-on experience with different materials processing methods as well as ways of analyzing a materials' structure for material properties.
I learned how to think deeper about materials science, how to problem solve in a lab, and how to write a proper report.
Gave a better understanding of material science and engineering as a whole
I honed my abilities to work within a lab environment and improved my understanding of the mechanical properties of materials through hands-on experimentation.
key mechanical engineering manufacturing and testing techniques
I learned several lab techniques used to study new and existing materials.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The labs were interesting and different each week so we learned many different techniques for analysis. I think it was good that we had to write a mini lab report after each session so that we could get feedback and space out the work.

Strengths: good introduction to techniques used in materials science, manageable workload. Weaknesses: assignment expectations were not always clear in terms of what kinds of analysis and discussion needed to be addressed
The machines are too old to yield the best data, so lab machines are needed.

Strengths: very engaging and interesting 
Weakness: too much work for a 0.5 credit class

I gained a lot from the course, but if taken as a "fifth class" it can feel fairly rigorous. I would say additionally that some of the experiments were hindered by the lack of proper/quality lab machines or devices. Therefore, the class and labs would go more smoothly if there were more accurate machines.

This course consisted of a twice weekly lecture and an evening lab session. Lectures often had very little bearing on what was studied during lab sessions, and also felt repetitive given the fact that I was concurrently taking materials science. This course is also only worth a half credit despite requiring much more class time than some full credit courses.

Another way this course could be improved is by updating the testing equipment used in 286L. For example, the Instron machine in our lab classroom was very old and lacked a lot of the modern functions and capabilities of newer models, which would have helped with an experiment we ran at the end of the course.

Also, the only grade we receive for this course is a final lab report. Although we submitted small reports throughout, those were not graded and we did not receive much feedback on them, so I have no idea how I did in this course upon finishing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think it's a good class to get experience with running the various tests and being able to analyze materials. It also helps you get a better understanding of materials science in general and can help you better understand choices about materials in other engineering projects.
The labs are engaging, you just have to make sure you keep up with your work or else you'll be swamped near the end of the semester when you're drafting your final report and presentation.
Yes, it is a great course for people interested in materials science.
Yes if they are interested in material science. But it is more work than other 0.5 credit classes which makes it hard to recommend
For mechanical engineers

This course definitely helps one get comfortable in a lab setting, which is extremely useful if you intend to conduct research while in college. Labs were interesting and we also got to use a lot of equipment that would otherwise be off-limits to undergrads, such as electron microscopes. For anyone in mechanical engineering (or even chemical), MENG 286L is worth taking.
